title.narrative: Carter Center -Stöd till demokratisk styrning och mänskliga rättigheter
The Carter Center - Advancing Democratic Governance & Respect for HR/2017-2019

description.narrative: Insatsen ska bidra till att nå målen för Sveriges strategi för utvecklingssamarbete i DRK 2015-2019 och då speciellt området - Stärkt kapacitet i det civila samhället att verka för öppenhet, ansvarsutkrävande och ökad respekt för mänskliga rättigheter. Insatsen uppgår till 30 mkr för en 3 -årsperiod och Carter Center (TCC) är genomförare. TCC ska arbeta för att stärka det civila samhället i DRK i sin roll att övervaka och rapportera om mänskliga rättigheter, gruvnäringen och politiska val samt att ta fram underlag till kampanjer inom dessa områden. TCC ska stärka civila samhällsorganisationer att nå ut till marginaliserade grupper, stärka ungdomsorganisationer samt stärka nämnda organisationers interna kapacitet inom t ex intern styrning och kontroll.

The Carter Center (TCC) has applied to Sida for funding of 30 million SEK to carry out the “ Advancing democratic governance and respect for human rights in the DRC” project during the period 2017-2020. The intervention aims at : 1) Improved monitoring, analysis, and reporting 2) Enhanced advocacy for reform 3) Increased community engagement 4) Strengthened organisational capacity The organisation implementing the intervention is The Carter Center. The project is fully financed by Sweden, it is based on TCCs country program, but TCC itself allocates also internal resources for its implementation. Other donors are also funding TCCs work in DRC in similar areas, based on TCCs country program. The budget is divided with: 7 000 000 SEK for the year 2017 13 000 000 SEK for the year 2018 10 000 000 SEK for the year 2019 The project will target Congolese Human Rights CSOs, Young civil society leaders and extractive industries. Sweden has previously supported TCCs work in the DRC with app. 30 MSEK for 2013-2106. An external evaluation of this support was undertaken in 2016 showing positive outcomes.

The programme describes how TCC intends to advance democratic governance and respect of human rights as well strengthen youth political participation in the DRC. It also describes objectives and proposed results, mainly focused on the better understanding of the democratic process, motoring of natural resources, capacity of women and youth leaders and activists to engage in democratic debate and to improve resilience in managing security threats, especially during the electoral period.

description.narrative: July 2019 starts the third year of the project. In 2018, the Human Rights Houses (HRH), implementation continued as planned, and additional partners for the youth houses were discussed. HRH implemented a needs assessment for 18 CSOs in 2017, and then added two more (total of 20). TCC/HRH has conducted training workshops on coalition building, democratic elections, and 6 round tables. The HRH has also started Democracy Bee competitions – currently 122 students in Goma (58 are female) have participated. Overall the number of female participants in activities has been increased. For citizen observation, in 2018 the Peace and Justice Commission (JPC) worked to support female candidates. Subgrant to work within provinces was approved. The Carter Center has worked closely with JPC to to build their capacity to collect and analyze data and publish reports. There were several activities and preparations leading up to the elections in December 2018, and the embassy provided a specific support to JPC via TCC for their specific electoral mission in the 2018 elections. As for governance of the extractive industry, given the current political situation and the likely prospects for the situation after the elections, the Carter Center ensured that all of its activities were transparent vis-à-vis the authorities and companies, making sure that they are informed about the activities undertaken. In 2018 TCC also conducted a Human Rights Impact Assessments of extractive projects, with reports expected throughout 2019.
